text: this is Anthony Shadid reporting from
the New York Times the road to Tripoli
is about an eight-hour drive that seems
to capture the hopes ambitions anxieties
and fears of a country wrestling with
its future it begins at the Tunisian
backwater town of the Heba made
prominent because of the revolution
across its border a queue of cars awaits
the custom post where people gather the
conversations are about what lay ahead
their expressions of jubilation as well
as anxiety some people hope that Colonel
Muammar Qaddafi will be captured soon
others expressed a seemingly simple
sentiment they wanted to be proud again
of handing her passport to the customs
agents I was for the first time against
they honestly say that I feel honestly
yeah I'm to be Olivia and I spent he is
kind of denying it or hiding myself you
know what I mean for the north
Santana's a city and the throes of
tumult traffic snarls around roundabouts
that no longer have police to organize
them
one volunteer 61 year old man had taken
his perch and one of those roundabouts
blowing his whistle and Cecily he was
directing traffic
he used the roundabout as a soapbox to
deliver a line of poetry I'm in heretic
to judge about the villages and towns
that lay on the road from Xin tan to
Tripoli or at least reminiscent of Iraq
in April 2003 another moment of upheaval
one of those towns is beautif annum
rebels as young as 15 years old
swaggered around the streets with the
rifles some of the brand-new we passed a
convoy of rebels headed to Tripoli where
the fight goes on all the rebels have
taken control of most of the capital
there are still pockets of resistance in
the fighting is fierce the road descends
to the coastal plain the town of Zawiya
and then across to Tripoli both places
bear the scars of the recent fighting
sand berms have spilled across the
asphalt
detr√°s of the battle is strewn through
the street and bags of trash have
accumulated on the roadside there's no
sense of normalcy these days as far as
normal went in the era of Colonel
Muammar Qaddafi no one seems quite sure
where events are headed the fall of the
capital that played out in days may
inaugurate a much longer process one
that lasts weeks months and perhaps even
years
